content: Singaporean Policeman and Dancer **Felix Cheong** (born 1965, Singapore) is a [Singaporean](/wiki/Singapore) [author](/wiki/Author) and [poet](/wiki/Poet). He received the [National Arts Council](/wiki/National_Arts_Council,_Singapore) [Young Artist Award](/wiki/Singapore_Young_Artist_Award) for Literature in 2000. Cheong has written over 30 books across genres including poetry, young adult fiction, and graphic novels. ## Early life and education Cheong spent his early childhood years in a *kampong* in Lorong 3, Geylang. He has one older brother and two younger brothers. Born to two Catholic parents, Cheong has described Catholicism as having a profound impact on his writing. Cheong attended St. Anthony's Boys' School and represented the school in table tennis. He then attended St. Joseph's Institution, where he was a member of the school band and the Literary, Drama and Debate Society. In 1990, Cheong graduated from the [National University of Singapore](/wiki/National_University_of_Singapore) with a Bachelor of Arts (Honors) in English Literature and Philosophy, and a minor in English Language. In June 2002, he completed his Masters of Philosophy in Creative Writing at the [University of Queensland](/wiki/University_of_Queensland) on a bursary awarded by the National Arts Council. ## Career Cheong started his career as a broadcast journalist with the then-[Singapore Broadcasting Corporation](/wiki/Mediacorp), where he worked for two years. He then joined CNBC Asia as a studio director for close to eight years. He later embarked on a freelance writing career before becoming a teacher. He has since taught at institutions such as LaSalle College, University of Newcastle, and the National University of Singapore. Cheong's first collection of poetry, *Temptation and Other Poems* ([ISBN](/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)) 9789813065178) was published in 1998 followed by a second collection in 1999, *I Watch the Stars Go Out* ([ISBN](/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)) 9789810411275), *Broken by the Rain* ([ISBN](/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)) 9789810480332) in 2003, and *Sudden in Youth: New and Selected Poems* ([ISBN](/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)) 9789810834128) in 2009. Cheong has written two young adult fiction [books](/wiki/Book) used as part of a national education campaign â€“ *The Call From Crying House* ([ISBN](/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)) 9789814189057) and its sequel, *The Woman In The Last Carriage* ([ISBN](/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)) 9789814189118). Cheong won the National Arts Council's Young Artist of the Year for Literature Award in 2000 and the [poetry slam](/wiki/Poetry_slam) at the [Hong Kong International Literary Festival](/wiki/Hong_Kong_International_Literary_Festival) in 2004. His poems have been featured in various projects, including Singapore Poetry on the Sidewalks in 2016 and Poems on the MRT. ## Selected publications ### Poetry - *The Mischief of Ordinary Things* (2024, Marshall Cavendish Editions) ISBN 9815169181, 9789815169188 - *B-SIDES AND BACKSLIDES: 1986 -2018* (2018, Math Paper Press) [ISBN](/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)) 9811173044 - *Broken by the Rain* (2003, Firstfruits) [ISBN](/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)) 9810480334 - *I Watch the Stars Go Out* (1999, [Ethos Books](/wiki/Ethos_Books)) [ISBN](/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)) 9810411278 - *Temptation, and Other Poems* (1998, Landmark Books) [ISBN](/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)) 9813065176 ### Fiction - *Singapore Siu Dai 2: The SG Conversation Upsize!* (2014, [Ethos Books](/wiki/Ethos_Books)) [ISBN](/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)) 978-981-09-2549-9 - *Singapore Siu Dai: The SG Conversation In A Cup* (2014, [Ethos Books](/wiki/Ethos_Books)) [ISBN](/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)) 9789810788582 - *Vanishing Point* (2012, [Ethos Books](/wiki/Ethos_Books)) [ISBN](/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)) 9789810733865 - *Sudden in Youth: New & Selected Poems* (2009, [Ethos Books](/wiki/Ethos_Books)) [ISBN](/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)) 9789810834128 - *The Woman in the Last Carriage* (2007, Landmark Books) [ISBN](/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)) 9814189111 - *The Call from the Crying House* (2006, Landmark Books) [ISBN](/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)) 9814189057 - *Different* (2005, [Ethos Books](/wiki/Ethos_Books)) [ISBN](/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)) 9810537654 - *Idea to Ideal: 12 Singapore Poets on the Writing of their Poems* (editor; 2004, Firstfruits) [ISBN](/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)) 981051686X ### Graphic novels - *The Showgirl and the Minister* (2023, Penguin Random House SEA) ISBN 9789815144314 - *Goh Keng Swee: A Singaporean for All Seasons* (2023, Marshall Cavendish International) ISBN 9789815113419 - Official website This article about a Singaporean poet is a stub.
